business_hypothesis: A small subset of billing users/senders (billing_user_id, entered_user_id) produce most malformed dates and mis-routed charges, creating concentrated operational risk.
science_hypothesis: billing_user_id and entered_user_id explain a non-trivial share of variance in malformed_date rate and recognized total_charges via a mixed-effects model: billing_user_id random effect variance component >= 10% of total variance and between-user difference in malformed_date rate >= 0.20 (expected effect size analogous to Cohen's d >= 0.45 for user groups).
null_case: Malformed_date incidents are uniformly distributed across users: per-user malformed_date rate variance is consistent with random binomial variation (variance explained by billing_user_id < 2%) and no users exceed population mean by >2 standard deviations (p > 0.10 after multiple-test correction).

validation_methods.execution_plan: Aggregate records by billing_user_id and compute malformed_date_rate = count(malformed_date)/count(records) and mean recognized_total = mean(total_charges where invoiced_flag=true). Then flag users with malformed_date_rate > population_mean + 2*population_std and test significance with a binomial proportion test adjusted for multiple comparisons. Pass criterion: at least one user meets the hotspot condition with p <= 0.01 and effect size (rate difference) >= 0.20.

Create cohorts by billing_user_id and compute per-cohort distributions of time_to_invoice, malformed_date_rate, and average total_charges recognized; then run pairwise Mannâ€“Whitney tests comparing top-decile users vs bottom-decile users with FDR correction. Pass criterion: top-decile vs bottom-decile comparisons show statistically significant differences (p <= 0.01) in malformed_date_rate and time_to_invoice with effect sizes >= 0.45.

Fit a mixed-effects model total_charges ~ malformed_date + (1 | billing_user_id) + canceled + is_summary_bill and report variance partitioning (ICC) and likelihood-ratio test for the random effect. Pass criterion: ICC for billing_user_id >= 0.10 and LRT p <= 0.01 indicating user-level effects materially explain variation.
